
An outdated vault locks secrets with RSA, but the keys are built from blum integers—two primes, both ≡ 3 mod 4. Can you break the encryption and reveal 6164954735914039906920076533000288733975713393266688968136295593671061809353840510713766122397404793931019460110916899430724064949192431116530403514448156?


The flag format is flag{...}
n=9428602206363089770269867962011327842279377981490035271907916211919226622046220292260623940213268049534926415608175176843403916524887509900966135490954557, e=6242954061821325099847744304577212465744493430276445768719547658527370189255622526247768276517720326124153549858414930645804416966367773676694737335861601
The lower 104 bits of p are: 17918910408290066738916448552962722279


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{ch880r3e}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 6164954735914039906920076533000288733975713393266688968136295593671061809353840510713766122397404793931019460110916899430724064949192431116530403514448156
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=9428602206363089770269867962011327842279377981490035271907916211919226622046220292260623940213268049534926415608175176843403916524887509900966135490954557, e=6242954061821325099847744304577212465744493430276445768719547658527370189255622526247768276517720326124153549858414930645804416966367773676694737335861601
